b19bfcbd7b695025e49d546be54e168b (00:22): well, it is more like 4.5, and we are certainly less likely to provide big features, unless we just lift them off Apple, which is still possible.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:24): with not providing "big features" you mean not keeping up with the rest or not having lots of time to innovate yourselves?

b19bfcbd7b695025e49d546be54e168b (00:25): I mean stuff like local DB, etc. I don't think we're really interested in innovating stuff, since realistically no one will use any extensions if we fell like inventing them.
b19bfcbd7b695025e49d546be54e168b (00:25): I think you Opera folks should have a good idea of that... Well, I've certainly considered ripping off the browser JavaScript idea :-)

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:30): You can innovate extensions then promote them as standards and have other browsers implement them and then people will start using the extensions and you'll already support them :-)

b19bfcbd7b695025e49d546be54e168b (00:31): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: you need spare manpower for that, though. And you need to be able to deal with stuff suddenly breaking, like IIRC it did on some sites for Opera due to WebForms 2.0
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:32): yeah, WF2 causes issues now and then
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:33): It's best if those issues get discovered in browsers with very few users, so the specs can be fixed before anyone else is affected ;-)

65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (00:42): whether UA checks are a problem depends on the type of site
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (00:42): unfortunately, fancy advanced "web app" type sites are the most likely to completely lock you out based on UA string
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (00:42): or otherwise rely on UA testing in a bad way
b19bfcbd7b695025e49d546be54e168b (00:43): 8782ac0c77935b842ee42d72f487cef5: looks fine, in both 3.5.something and 4.0.1-pre. Except it doesn't look so hot at 1024x768

8782ac0c77935b842ee42d72f487cef5 (00:43): Normally if I'm working on a site design I'll write it in a compliant browser (generally I'll start off with Firefox, then make sure it works in standards-compliant browsers by testing in Opera) and then provide fixes for IE using conditional comments.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:43): Fancy advanced "web app" types sites are the most likely to do X, for any action X :-)

8782ac0c77935b842ee42d72f487cef5 (00:44): b19bfcbd7b695025e49d546be54e168b: Yeah, one thing I'm going to do is take out the 200px left margin - that's a relic from when I had an image there I wanted to show through. :P

65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (00:44): a certain Major Web App Vendor has code in many of their web apps that test if you have certain combinations of methods and properties available on the DOM Element and Document interfaces, and if so assumes what browser you are, and then makes completely unrelated assumptions
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (00:44): because their experts on the matter told them not to test the UA string
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (00:45): so they ended up finding a way to do it even worse
b19bfcbd7b695025e49d546be54e168b (00:45): heh. browser fingerprinting is a fun topic, though.
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (00:45): (we found out because in Safari we fixed what methods were on Document and Element to better match other browsers, and they no longer detected us as Safari)
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (00:45): (so they started using Firefox designMode hacks instead of contentEditable for editing)

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:11): Has anybody already mentioned that <canvas> ImageData won't work with high-end display systems that use 12-bit colour components, or floating point components?
b19bfcbd7b695025e49d546be54e168b (01:14): I guess it should permit better precision in the same range?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:15): That wouldn't help the floating-point HDR case, though maybe that case is a bit too theoretical
b19bfcbd7b695025e49d546be54e168b (01:16): I suppose the clamping is the right behavior for a non-HDR implementation on HDR data, or am I mistaken?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:17): Depends on whether you consider data loss to be "right behavior" :-)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (01:19): css has the same issue
b19bfcbd7b695025e49d546be54e168b (01:19): well, premultiplied alpha is data loss, too ....
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (01:19): although CSS has the weird thing that it allows percentages too which allow for a far larger range than the integer alternative
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:20): When we all have cyborg eyes that can detect four distinct colours, all this three-component RGB legacy will be a real pain
b19bfcbd7b695025e49d546be54e168b (01:20): It definitely seems like something that should be permitted. So if an implementation supports 9 bits,and is given 179.5, it can represent it well.
